headline: ‘Wyrmwood: Apocalypse’ Review: Maximum Zombie Slayage
abstract: In this Australian zombie sequel, a soldier helps a pack of vigilantes rise up against his evil boss.
lead_paragraph: “Wyrmwood: Road of the Dead” was about as calm as a Chihuahua on cocaine, and its new sequel is no exception. The opening titles for “Wyrmwood: Apocalypse” appear over sounds of chaos: tires screeching, machine guns firing, zombies wailing. If you’d like to see the horror-action equivalent of an old metal rock musician lighting his electric guitar on fire and then playing it with his teeth, this is your movie.

headline: ‘Fantastic Beasts: The Secrets of Dumbledore’ Review: The Plot Against Muggles
abstract: Mads Mikkelsen plays an evil wizard with political talent in the latest “Harry Potter” spinoff movie, which also stars Jude Law and Eddie Redmayne.
lead_paragraph: Like so much children’s entertainment these days, “Fantastic Beasts: The Secrets of Dumbledore” is a political primer sprinkled in magic dust. In this third installment in the “Fantastic Beasts” franchise (itself a prequel series to the original “Harry Potter” stories), cuddly critters have mostly been swapped out for darker creatures: Here, scorpionesque freaks guard a prison where activists are tortured (or worse). A chunk of the story is set in 1930s Berlin. The deadly stakes are crystal-ball clear. An alternate subtitle could be “Totalitarianism for Tykes.”

headline: ‘Dual’ Review: Seeing Double, Inviting Trouble
abstract: A woman prepares to battle her clone in Riley Stearns’s imprecise satire that invites questions about the self and then leaves them unexplored.
lead_paragraph: The premise of “Dual,” which hinges on a woman feuding with her clone, feels as if it were cooked up after skimming a book of Jungian psychology. It takes place in a woodland dystopia where cloning is an option for terminal patients seeking to replace themselves. The pair cannot coexist, however; should the sick person recover, he or she must duel the clone to decide who lives on. It’s ego death, literalized.

headline: ‘The Tale of King Crab’ Review: In Exile, Both at Home and Abroad
abstract: This fiction feature debut follows a scandalous son of a physician turned adventurer in spite of himself.
lead_paragraph: The two Italian filmmakers Alessio Rigo de Righi and Matteo Zoppis, who make their fiction feature debut with “The Tale of King Crab,” are clearly attracted to loners. Their 2015 documentary feature “Il Solengo” explores the world of a real-life contemporary hermit. “King Crab” begins in the same hunting lodge that figured in “Il Solengo” and their 2013 documentary short “Belva Nera.” Here, a group of aging men share a meal and talk about an old story, one of “princes and poor people.”

headline: We Always Give Generous Gifts. Why Are My In-Laws So Cheap?
abstract: A reader feels slighted after years of lavishing her sister-in-law’s children with quality presents.
lead_paragraph: My husband’s brother and his wife have three children. For nearly 14 years, we’ve given their kids generous gifts for birthdays and at Christmas. It was our pleasure to do so — until six years ago, when we had a son, and my sister-in-law started buying him junk gifts that cost a fraction of what we spend on their children. Their most recent gift to our son (a flimsy superhero coloring book for his sixth birthday) was so lousy that he started crying when he unwrapped it. The imbalance makes me angry, on his behalf and on mine. What can I do?

headline: ‘Paris, 13th District’ Review: Groping Toward Happiness
abstract: In his latest movie, the French director Jacques Audiard tells the story of lovers finding their way in Paris.
lead_paragraph: In “Paris, 13th District,” a very French French movie, he loves and she loves, but they don’t love each other, not exactly, or maybe not just yet. That’s how it goes with affairs of the heart, onscreen and off. Desire is tricky, mercurial, alternately fleeting and enduring, tragic and transcendent. But in French cinema it often seems unfailingly beautiful, exalted. That’s the case here, with lovely people exchanging caresses as the filmmaking elevates their every breathless moment, and their naked bodies offer their own pleasures.

The pause gave her a much-needed break from touring, but then late last year her return to the stage was thwarted when she contracted Covid-19 on the road, despite being vaccinated, and had to cancel the remainder of her shows, again.

headline: Christopher Moore, Preserver of Black New York History, Dies at 70

lead_paragraph: The imposing palazzo that sits at Via della Moscova 33 in Milan’s well-heeled Brera district was once a nexus of the local silk trade. Industrialists and artisans would travel from across Italy to the building, constructed in the late 19th century and known as the Cortile della Seta, to meet, trade and vote on industry matters. During World War II, the structure was destroyed by bombs; it was later rebuilt and used as a bank. As of this year, though, when it became the headquarters for Loro Piana, as well as the site of the 98-year-old brand’s second store devoted to interiors, the palazzo is once again home to high-end textiles.

headline: The Case for Criticism
abstract: Experts say fear keeps us from sharing constructive feedback, but here’s how — and why — you should speak up anyway.
lead_paragraph: One thing I want to improve about myself is my ability to tell other people how to improve themselves. I am terrible at giving constructive feedback. I recently hired an administrative assistant, and I find myself far more inclined to praise her for how well she’s doing than to provide suggestions that might help her do an even better job — even though doing so would not only benefit her but also directly benefit me.

headline: A Financial Services Company Illegally Leased Dogs, Massachusetts Says
abstract: Monterey Financial Services LLC has agreed to pay $930,000 in debt relief and restitution to settle allegations that it was conducting the practice, which is banned in the Bay State and others.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Catalina Ortiz-Sierra lost her job and failed to make payments on what she thought was a loan, a collections agent in 2019 threatened to take away her dog, Milo, a Shih Tzu-poodle mix.

headline: Review: ‘Cyrano de Bergerac,’ Now Noseless and Drunk on Words
abstract: James McAvoy gives a ravishing performance, without benefit of prosthetics or props, in a new adaptation alive with the love of language.
lead_paragraph: “Ah, good my lords, what a nose is his! When one sees it, one is fain to cry aloud, ‘Nay! ’tis too much!’”

headline: Honoring the Past by Focusing on the Future
abstract: Named after a team from the Negro leagues, the Nashville Stars give young players, Black and white, passion and purpose in the game.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It’s fitting that the Nashville Stars, a team for players ages 10 and under, are named in honor of an old Negro leagues team that played in Music City in the 1930s, ’40s, and ’50s. From the aggressive base running to the all-Black coaching staff and the speaker blaring a mix of hip-hop and R&B from the bleachers, the Stars embody the energy and excitement that made pre-integration Black baseball a cultural phenomenon as much as a sporting attraction. The team also serves as a stark contradiction of the stereotypical image of American youth baseball.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Presses Stephen Miller on Whether Trump Sought to Incite Crowd
keywords: ['Project: Democracy', 'Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: In about eight hours of questioning, investigators pressed the former White House aide on former President Donald J. Trump’s use of “we” in his speech to supporters before the riot.
lead_paragraph: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol spent roughly eight hours on Thursday questioning Stephen Miller, a top White House adviser to former President Donald J. Trump, in an at times contentious exchange that included queries about Mr. Trump’s speech before a crowd the morning of the riot, according to two people familiar with the session.

headline: Kisses and Hugs
abstract: Trenton Charlson outfoxes us by thinking outside the box, without pushing the envelope.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — A Trenton Charlson puzzle is a good companion for a gray day, a blah day — or a day when you find out that in spite of all those precautions your faraway friends teased you for taking, you have landed in the Covid zone.

headline: Review: In ‘American Buffalo,’ Grift Is the Coin of the Realm
abstract: Sam Rockwell, Laurence Fishburne and Darren Criss star in an electric revival of the David Mamet play about capitalism in a junk shop.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday’s edition of the Fox News show “Life, Liberty & Levin,” David Mamet, the playwright turned Trumpite culture warrior, made an incendiary comment.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Daniel Raymon rustles up a real challenge.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — This puzzle, a tough example of the Puns and Anagrams genre, is by a multitalented Times constructor, Daniel Raymon, who makes cryptic crosswords and daily grids as well. If you’ve been wondering about trying cryptics, I think if you can get through this grid, you’ll be ready to try more. It’s not that “Panda” puzzles are easy, but they do follow regular crossword rules: Every square is crossed by two entries, so you have two chances to figure everything out. There are also far more anagrams, which usually help a solver out. On the other hand, the puns can be pretty wild.

headline: A California legislator ended his efforts to pass a vaccine mandate for students.
abstract: The bill would have eliminated a personal belief exemption that has been used to circumvent similar mandates.
lead_paragraph: A bill that would have required all California students to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, eliminating a personal belief exemption that has been used to circumvent similar mandates, was pulled by its legislative sponsor on Thursday.

headline: Slowing Down Sped Up Their Relationship
abstract: Kabir Melwani and Leah Madeline Freedland met in graduate school, but really bonded while living in his parents’ home for months during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Kabir Melwani and Leah Madeline Freedland are never at a loss for adjectives when each is asked to describe the other.

headline: Bonding Over Faith and Football
abstract: Janice Matamoros and Rayburn Ewers, both octogenarians, met after moving to a senior living community in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Janice Matamoros and Rayburn Ewers, who goes by Otto, each prayed a lot before moving to the Belmont Village Senior Living community in Lakeway, Texas, in 2019. Though both of their prayers were answered, hers came with a bit of a twist.

headline: The Loneliness of the Locked-Down Single Mother
abstract: Having a job, a child and no help during a pandemic can take a toll — but also forge a special bond.
lead_paragraph: It began with a missing package. One day I got a message from a stranger on LinkedIn: “You don’t know me, but I live across the street, and I think I have your package.”

headline: Two Epic Dates and an Incredible Arcade Game Feat
abstract: Jennifer Banegas proposed to Alyssa Bush with a video game scoreboard and the words: “Ken Wil You Mar Me?”
lead_paragraph: When Alyssa Bush traveled from Baltimore to Seattle in February 2019, it was mainly to visit a friend with a new baby. But she also wanted to explore the city. With her friend preoccupied by parenthood, Ms. Bush logged into Tinder and Bumble, hoping to connect with someone she could meet for a drink or a meal. On both dating apps, she matched with Jennifer Banegas.

headline: The Cat’s Approval Was a Good Start
abstract: After nearly two decades together, Stuart Rembaum and Jim Post finally agreed to marry — but not before Mr. Rembaum’s cat “sanctioned the relationship” by allowing Mr. Post to pet her.
lead_paragraph: Even after being together for nearly two decades, Stuart Rembaum still struggled to find the words when it came to discussing a possible wedding to Jim Post.

headline: In a Week, Moving a Wedding from Ukraine to New York
abstract: In their last phone call before they married, Meny Stambler, who is Ukrainian, and Rikel Deutch, who is Russian, expected to wed in Ukraine. Hours after they hung up, Russian troops had invaded.
lead_paragraph: On a Wednesday evening in late February, Meny Stambler and Rikel Deutch talked to each other on the phone for the last time before their wedding.

headline: Moving From Elegy to Ecstasy, a Poet Pushes Against the Canon
abstract: In “Best Barbarian,” Roger Reeves riffs on Western tradition to challenge its omissions and expand its political and artistic possibilities.
lead_paragraph: Proceeding in prayerlike incantation, “Best Barbarian,” Roger Reeves’s terrific second collection, eruditely sets out to unite the Western literary canon with its omissions and oppressions. These poems resurrect an eclectic cast of characters, from Sappho to James Baldwin, to reflect on the poet’s vital yet unanswerable question: “What disaster will I deliver to my daughter?” From playful abecedarians to a psychedelic “durational” poem (which, when read aloud, is roughly the length of the Alice Coltrane song that inspired it) the reader traverses a sonic landscape from elegy to ecstasy.

headline: He Never Existed. Here Are His Selected Poems.
abstract: In “Madness,” the poet Gabriel Ojeda-Sagué has assembled a career retrospective for a writer he invented from whole cloth.
lead_paragraph: In his innovative fourth poetry collection, “Madness,” Gabriel Ojeda-Sagué imagines the life and work of a fictional “minor” poet named Luis Montes-Torres, who is said to have been born in 1976 and to have died of complications from brain cancer at the age of 58, in 2035. “Madness” is presented as a retrospective volume of his selected poems, published with analysis and commentary 20 years after his death.

headline: A Poet Who Looks at the Stuff of Daily Life and Sees Looming Apocalypse
abstract: Again and again in Ange Mlinko’s collection “Venice,” quotidian events generate nightmarish overtones.
lead_paragraph: Ange Mlinko’s poems are animated by an unusual combination of impulses. They are formal, highly polished, with hard, smooth surfaces and dense interiors, the products of intense and serious craft. But whereas formal so often suggests staid or restrained, Mlinko’s poems are anything but. They are wild, energetic, alive, wantonly catholic in their allusiveness, often downright chatty. Some have the feel of postcards, especially in their opening lines. “The hotel showers were splendidly profligate,” begins one poem in “Venice,” Mlinko’s sixth collection. The next one starts: “After the olivine waves of Marina di Torre del Lago,/we drive between colonnades of umbrella pines.”

headline: Best Known as a Holocaust Poet, Nelly Sachs Deserves Another Look
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: The Nobel laureate’s postwar collection “Flight and Metamorphosis,” published in 1959 and newly translated into English, reveals a poet full of mystery and depth.
lead_paragraph: An inviting poem is usually easy to understand; a good poem — inviting or not — usually complicates into surprise and depth. The poems in Nelly Sachs’s “Flight and Metamorphosis,” first published in German in 1959 and newly translated by the poet-critic-scholar Joshua Weiner (with Linda B. Parshall), seem little interested in invitation. But they are full of shifting surprises, mysteries and depths.

headline: One Last Book From an Outback Poet Who Was Part Hero, Part Pariah
abstract: Les Murray’s posthumous collection “Continuous Creation” highlights both his crankiness and the rough magnificence of the landscape he loved.
lead_paragraph: Born and raised in New South Wales, Australia, Les Murray was gaptoothed, pigheaded, booming, burly. (He would have said fat.) His childhood in Bunyah was not a long way from nowhere — you’d have to pass Coolongolook, Cooranbong and a lot of other one-kangaroo towns to get to Sydney, three hours away. A lover of the outback, molded but not deformed by university, he was proud of not belonging, boasting his degree the “least distinguished” ever bestowed by the University of Sydney. The best poet Australia had seen for a generation or two, by his early 30s he lived in partial exile from the literary scene. His longing for the bush grew until in his 40s he moved back to part of the old family dairy farm.

headline: Facing ‘the Can’t-See of the Future,’ in Verse and at the Chiropractor’s
abstract: In “Now Do You Know Where You Are,” the poet Dana Levin learns to write again and comes to terms with personal and political trauma.
lead_paragraph: There are two kinds of poets in the world — poets who write poetry, and poets who don’t. I fall into the second company as of late. So do many of my literary acquaintances. Mostly we write plaintive emails to each other about not writing poetry. It’s almost a genre.

headline: A Poet Looks at the End of the World, and Reaches for Hope
abstract: In “Canopy,” her seventh collection, Linda Gregerson mourns for humanity and the earth even as she clings to signs of personal connection.
lead_paragraph: What should we do about the end of the world? What about the end of our own lives? What should we say if we can’t do anything? Such questions have a history in poems as old as the history of poems: They animate funeral elegies, prayers to forestall the apocalypse, deathbed repentance like John Donne’s. And they have new resonance now, when climate change and global plague and general public exhaustion have put so many of us into such a rough mood, “casting about for ways to summon normal,” as the careful, careworn, learned Michigan poet Linda Gregerson says. Gregerson’s seventh collection tries patiently and concisely to support our aging bodies, our battered ecosystems and our traditions of memorable speech, along with her own Midwestern immigrant heritage with its “Scandinavian Grim.”

lead_paragraph: The nicknames are familiar to those with long memories: the New Jersey Generals, the Philadelphia Stars, the Tampa Bay Bandits. So is the league name: the U.S.F.L.

headline: In Edna St. Vincent Millay’s Diaries, the Private Life of a Celebrity Poet
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Seven decades after Millay’s death, “Rapture and Melancholy” paints a picture of artistic triumph, romantic tumult and a daily life that descended into addiction.
lead_paragraph: Edna St. Vincent Millay (1892-1950) was once the most famous poet in America. Her collections sold tens of thousands of copies, and her readings filled theaters from New York to Texas. She was the female voice of the Jazz Age, the New Woman incarnate whose passionate and iconoclastic verse earned her a devoted following. Her 1920 poem “First Fig” became an anthem for a generation tired of Victorian mores:

headline: The Shape of the Void: Toward a Definition of Poetry
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Language and Languages', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: “Poetry leaves something out,” our columnist Elisa Gabbert says. But that’s hardly the extent of it.
lead_paragraph: I once heard a student say poetry is language that’s “coherent enough.” I love a definition this ambiguous. It’s both helpful (there’s a limit to coherence, and the limit is aesthetic) and unhelpful (enough for what, or whom?). It reminds me of a dictionary entry for “detritus” that I copied down in a notebook: “the pieces that are left when something breaks, falls apart, is destroyed, etc.” That seemed so artfully vague to me, so uncharacteristically casual for a dictionary. It has a quality of distraction, of trailing off, of suggesting you already know what detritus means. Part of me resists the question of what poetry is, or resists the answer — you already know what it means.

headline: A Poet’s Poet: The Astonishing Career of John Keats
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Content Type: Personal Profile']
abstract: Robert Pinsky reviews Lucasta Miller’s “Keats: A Brief Life in Nine Poems and One Epitaph.”
lead_paragraph: Early in her book about John Keats, Lucasta Miller calls Lord Byron an “aristocratic megastar.” That funny epithet is accurate for Byron’s more-than-superstar celebrity in his day. It also suggests the many ways Byron was the opposite of Keats. Miller quotes Byron, in a letter, referring to the younger and much less well-known poet as “Jack Keats or Ketch or whatever his names are.”

abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: SECOND PLACE, by Rachel Cusk. (Picador, 192 pp., $17.) Cusk’s first novel since her acclaimed Outline trilogy shares similarities to her previous work — a sharply observant narrator, meditations on themes of art, beauty and the “tyranny” of parenthood — but it is also a departure. Dwight Garner, the Times critic, commented that this book has “a swirling hothouse quality that’s new” and that it “pushes its needles into the red.”

headline: Newly Published Poetry, From Gaza to Zoom Rooms and More
abstract: A selection of new poetry collections, from Mosab Abu Toha, Marlanda Dekine, Basie Allen, Shane McCrae, Ama Asantewa Diaka, Mary Jo Salter, Eloisa Amezcua and D. Nurkse.
lead_paragraph: THINGS YOU MAY FIND HIDDEN IN MY EAR: Poems From Gaza, by Mosab Abu Toha. (City Lights, paper, $11.17.) Written from his native Gaza, Abu Toha’s accomplished debut contrasts scenes of political violence with natural beauty: In one poem, a “nightingale departs the wet earth” two stanzas before the “sound of a drone / intrudes.”

headline: What Good Friday and Easter Mean for Black Americans
keywords: ['Easter and Holy Week', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Jesus’ story does not end with his crucifixion. Similarly, racism will not have the final word.
lead_paragraph: I encountered my first corpse in middle school. My cousin Tammy, one of the most beautiful members of our family, died of complications from AIDS at the age of 28. The last time I saw her alive lesions covered the portions of her frail frame not draped in hospital blankets and IVs.

headline: Poems of Exile, Introspection and Self-Discovery (Cicadas, Too)
abstract: New collections from Akwaeke Emezi, Solmaz Sharif, Colm Toibin and Phoebe Giannisi.
lead_paragraph: In 39 concise, impactful poems, Akwaeke Emezi’s debut collection, CONTENT WARNING: EVERYTHING (47 pp., Copper Canyon, paperback, $16), is a triumph of selfhood that painstakingly journeys between belief and becoming. Holding tenderness and rage in one breath, the Nigerian-born nonbinary author excavates trauma, divorce and loss without restraint: “what wars have been fought on me what hauntings I carry in the blaze of/unspeakable light.” Emezi has previously written a memoir and screenplays as well as fiction, but poetry feels like a natural fit for the presumably autobiographical material in this collection, which often soothes as much as it shocks.

headline: Reporting From Amazon’s Hometown, and Seeing the Company Everywhere
abstract: Karen Weise, a technology correspondent, shares how she covers Amazon and its far-reaching businesses.
lead_paragraph: Karen Weise is a technology correspondent based in Seattle who has covered Amazon, which is headquartered there, for The Times since 2018. With its e-commerce operation, line of web services and grocery businesses, Amazon maintains a vast reach across American society. The company has been on a hiring spree in recent years, including a large push during the pandemic, which has brought its role as a major U.S. employer into sharper focus.

abstract: Do you participate in community events like parades, dances or concerts?
lead_paragraph: As pandemic restrictions ease, have you been able to gather with your community for block parties, fairs or festivals? How has it felt to come together in those ways again?

headline: In This Time of War, I Propose We Give Up God
abstract: Why would we emulate such terrible behavior?
lead_paragraph: This weekend, Jews around the world will celebrate the holiday of Passover, the name of which comes from the story of God “passing over” the homes of our distant ancestors on his way to slaughter the first born sons of evil Egyptians. Our forefathers, the story goes, marked their doorposts with lamb’s blood in order to spare their own sons the awful fate of their enemies.

headline: The Cruel Lesson of a Single Medical Mistake
keywords: ['Nursing and Nurses', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Malpractice', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A Tennessee nurse is facing prison time for a medical error.
lead_paragraph: We all carry the memory of our mistakes. For health care workers like me, these memories surface in the early morning when we cannot sleep or at a bedside where, in some way, we are reminded of a patient who came before. Most were errors in judgment or near misses: a procedure we thought could wait, a subtle abnormality in vital signs that didn’t register as a harbinger of serious illness, an X-ray finding missed, a central line nearly placed in the wrong blood vessel. Even the best of us have stories of missteps, close calls that are caught before they ever cause patient harm.

headline: How Love Changes Your Brain
abstract: In her new book, Stephanie Cacioppo, a neuroscientist, delves into romance, loss and human connection as she writes of her love story with her husband.
lead_paragraph: Can we do without love? For many years, the neuroscientist Stephanie Ortigue believed that the answer was yes. Even though she researched the science of human connections, Dr. Ortigue — an only child and, in her 20s and 30s, contentedly single — couldn’t completely grasp its importance in her own life.

headline: Military Memo Deepens Possible Interstellar Meteor Mystery
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Asteroids', 'Satellites', 'Meteors and Meteorites', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The U.S. Space Command seemed to confirm a claim that a meteor from outside the solar system had entered Earth’s atmosphere, but other scientists and NASA are still not convinced.
lead_paragraph: In early 2014, a dishwasher-size meteor dashed over the shores of Papua New Guinea before sunrise as it burned up in the fiery friction of Earth’s atmosphere. But two Harvard researchers argued that this wasn’t just any space rock: It originated from another star system, they said, making it the first observed meteor of interstellar origin.

headline: Wait, What if People Did Just Stay Home in Their Pajamas?
keywords: ['Coronavirus Return to Office', 'Workplace Environment', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Telecommuting']
abstract: New neighborhood businesses far from Midtown are thriving. Maybe it’s time to redefine what “comeback” means.
lead_paragraph: For several weeks now, Mayor Eric Adams has been obsessively pushing a recovery agenda hinged on the return of tens of thousands of workers to offices in Midtown and Lower Manhattan. In his plan, the pandemic would be left more or less to history when the starting bell signaling the return to normalcy rings. But the surreal counterprogramming of the past few days gave us, instead, a Covid-positive mayor addressing a rattled city from quarantine after a gunman opened fire on an N train in Brooklyn during rush hour on Tuesday morning.

headline: How Rocco DiSpirito, Chef, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Food is the focus, from afternoons at Balthazar to cooking for his family and friends at night.
lead_paragraph: Rocco DiSpirito has been a fixture on the American food scene since the 1990s. He has owned a three-star restaurant, been a reality television star and written over a dozen cookbooks, which range in theme from Italian American to “comfort keto.”

headline: How Barnes & Noble Went From Villain to Hero
abstract: To independent booksellers, the enormous chain was once a threat. Now it’s vital to their survival. And it’s doing well.
